text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen, I'm going to show

you how to make red velvet whoopie pies with
a marshmallow filling.

Now I've had a lot of you ask me if I could
show you this version of a whoopie pie because

I did make a chocolate version and I figured
there's no better time than the present, so,
let's get started!

The ingredients you'll need to make the actual
pies, the dough, are some all purpose flour,

cocoa powder, unsweetened, baking soda, baking
powder and salt, sugar, an egg, some unsalted

butter, ideally you want it softened, mine
melted a little because it's been sitting

on the stove, buttermilk, some red food coloring
and you're going to need some vanilla extract.

And in just a few minutes once these go into
the oven, I'll show you how to make the filling
as well.

So easy, I've got my oven pre-heated to 350,
I've got a couple of baking sheets ready with

some parchment paper so that we're ready to
rock and roll, and I'm only making a couple

dozen today, but you can, of course, double
the recipe and it'll make about 4 dozen, so

it's up to you, the problem is if there's
4 dozen, I will eat them!
You get the drift.
Ha!

I'm going to make mine in my standing mixer,
first thing I'm going to do is I have my paddle

attachment hooked on, I've got my butter,
I have my oven preheating and sometimes what

I'll do is I'll put my butter onto my stove
as my oven preheats and sometimes as you can

see it starts to melt a little bit but that's
fine, it'll be okay.

I'm just going to cream these two together
for about a minute.

Going to add my egg along with just a splash
of vanilla.
Not too much, just a little bit.

And I'm going to let that go for just a couple
of minutes as well, just want to make sure

it's well incorporated, you know the egg and
the butter and everything is nicely incorporated.

Okay, and of course you want to make sure
to give everything a mix and a stir around
the sides with a spatula every minute or so.

And then I'm going to add all of the dry ingredients
at once, and then along with that I'm going
to add some buttermilk.

Lift this up and then just mix it until you
can see you've got a creamy batter and it

will be thick but that's what you're looking
for.

And then at that point I can start adding
my food coloring.

Now I can start adding my food coloring and
you just add enough until you get your desired

color, you can also - you don't have to do
red you can do green for St Patrick's day,
you can do purple for Easter, you get it!
You got it!

I'm just going to keep mixing until it's the
right red for me and then I will show you
what it looks like when it gets there.

That looks excellent, just make sure like
I said you give everything a mix with your

spatula just in case there are a few things
under there that haven't been incorporated,

and then I just take a small ice cream scoop,
the equivalent of about a tablespoon and you

just make your little mounds and you want
to make sure you place them a couple inches
apart because they do spread.

So I'm going to make about two baking sheets
worth, and then we'll bake them.
Okay, last one!

I'm just going to pop these in, I've got both
baking sheets ready, they'll take about 10

to 12 minutes, you'll know they're done when
you touch the top of each one and it kind

of springs back, you know they're done, and
then as soon as they go in I'm going to clean

up and then get going on our filling which
we need to do right away!

To make the filling you're going to need some
confectioners sugar, this is some marshmallow

fluff, you'll find it in your regular grocery
store near the peanut butter.

I've got some unsalted butter that's been
softened at room temperature, I also have

a little bit of cream cheese that's also been
softened and some vanilla extract.

This is so easy and so simple, the first thing
I'n going to do is make it in my mixer here,

I'm going to take my butter and my cream cheese
and I'm just going to let that mix for a few
seconds just to loosen it up a bit.

Alright, just like to get some of that stuff
off.
Let me lower this.

I'm going to add pretty much everything else
at this point, we've got my sugar, my marshmallow

fluff, be careful because this is very, very
sticky, so have patience.
Get it all off of here.

And a splash of vanilla and now all I'm going
to do is mix this on medium speed for about
two minutes or until it's really lovely.
thick and well incorporated.
Excellent.
Okay, so, get this all off of the beater here.

Now a lot of people will go ahead and frost
them right now, which you can, but the thing

about marshmallow fluff is that, I don't know
if you can see but it gets really loose so

what I like to do is I like to pop this into
a bowl and then place it in the fridge and

then what happens is it hardens a little and
it makes it a lot easier for the filling to

stay in the whoopie pie, but if you are not
going to serve them right away, you're going

to want to put them in the fridge because
you can't keep them at room temperature because

the filling will sort of melt and loosen and
become a mess.

So what I'm going to do now is cover this,
I know it looks like a little but it's very
rich and sweet so a little goes a long way.

I'm going to cover this with some plastic
wrap and I'm going to stick it in the fridge

for about a half an hour or 45 minutes or
so and then we'll get going on stuffing them.

Alright, my little cakes are ready, my frosting
has had some time to set, and what I like

to do on the serving platter you're going
to serve them on, go ahead and sprinkle just

a little tiny bit of powdered sugar at the
bottom of your serving platter because it
helps them not stick to the serving dish.
How many times can I say serving platter?
Ha!

So I know that each baking sheet has 15 little
cakes on it so I'm going to go ahead and put

a dollop of this frosting on each one, now
these are obviously small, because that's

jut what I wanted to make - smaller sizes,
see?
This is what it'll look like.
Like that.
How adorable!

I'm just going to go ahead and pop them on
there, if you want to you could absolutely

make really big ones, with a big ice cream
scoop.
That would be really cool, I've done it.

When I made my chocolate ones, I used a whoopie
pie pan, you don't need it, I find that, to

me, to be honest, it's useless because They
come out just as well, if not better when

you do it this way, so there goes that for
what it's worth, you don't need a special
pan to make whoopie pies.
Don't they look so cute?

Now this one has my name written all over
it, I can just see it with my own two eyes!

So I'm just going to squish - look at that,
look how beautiful that filling is, it's not

grainy at all because we gave it time to mix
and then also it's had time to set so it's

not running off all over the place, but like
I mentioned, if you're not going to eat these

right away, make sure you store them in the
fridge, otherwise the filling will soften.
Mmm!
I love this so much I want to cry!

In my opinion they're the perfect size because
they're so rich and amazing, I hoe that you

give these a try, I promise you they will
not disappoint, they are phenomenal and I

know you will love them, go to LauraintheKitchen.com
to get the written recipe, I hope you've enjoyed

spending time with me and I'll see you next
time!
Bye!
